Description: Fragment of terracotta figurine of Harpokrates: head and shoulders. Head is solid but the body appears to have been hollow. Harpokrates is depicted with his right hand lifted to the mouth and wearing a compound festival wreath headdress, with the double crown of Egypt in the centre and two protrusions from the headdress at either side. Front is mould-made, from a worn mould. Covered in thick white coating, traces of bright red colour at mouth, eyebrows painted black (but this paint not on top of white coating?); traces of pink colour on headdress protrusions. Many features damaged. Cut off with a sharp edge at shoulder height. Brown micaceous Nile silt.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Bolton Museum. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

A parallel with a similar crown, but different hair, from Naukratis in Cambridge (MCA NA662, but without finger to mouth). A late 2nd century BC parallel (Bayer-Niemeier 1988, pl. 34.2, no.169), although this poor quality example may be Roman. Bayer-Niemeier, E. 1988. Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik. Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann, 1. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten. Melsungen.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.076) (Phase 1)
